bibl.title: Letter from George E. Bushnell to William C. Gorgas, April 16, 1906

div1.p: Bushnell recommends physician Alexander Murray to Gorgas for service in Panama and explains Murray's difficult circumstances owing to his wife's illness.

div1.head: Letter from George E. Bushnell to William C. Gorgas, April 16, 1906
div1.opener:
for Carter
Please return
Appl 915
Fort Bayard N. M
April 16th 1906
Colonel Wm. C. Gorgas
Med. Dept. U. S. Army
Ancon Panama
My dear Colonel Gorgas
div1.p:
Lieutenant Alexander
Murray of the Med. Dept. was in the Philippines
in 1903. His wife fell sick with pulmonary
tuberculosis in August of that year and returned to
the U. S. She came to New Mexico and at first lodged
with a ranchman five miles from this Hospital.
Her surroundings there were so unsuitable for a sick
woman that a place was made for her here. On my
application Lieut. Murray was relieved from duty
in the Philippines and assigned to duty here arriving
at this Hospital June 3d 1904, and has been on duty
here since that date. He leaves unofficially that he
is on the roster for Philippine duty in 1907 and it is
of course quite possible that if there is demand for
an increased medical force in the island that he may
be sent over during the present year under these
FILE
circumstances he has naturally given much anxious
the night as to what disposition he should make of his wife.
It will be necessary for her to remain in the Southwest
where living expenses are high. He is dependent entirely
upon his pay and in addition to his sick wife has
three young children to provide for. For the reasons
that he would receive larger pay and would be somewhat
nearer his wife he desires to be sent to Panama rather
than to the Philippines. He is a young man in excellent
health, of irreproachable habits, of good mental ability
and is a zealous and efficient medical officer. He has also
had training in a bank and is an expert accountant.
If there are any prospective vacancies in your force
one of which he could fill he would be willing to
accept the detail at any time, Lieut. Murray's case is
Known to the Surgeon General, who however does not know
of this officer's desire for Panama service. I am anxious
to help Murray and have written this personal letter
in advance of an official application to ask if you
think you could do anything to further that application
or if the conditions are such that it would be of
no use to apply for the detail.

Trusting that you will pardon me for this demand
upon the time of a busy man I am
